columns.text: For this exercise, we need to find which between two firms (A and B) has the best ROE (Return on Equity).

We know the following data:



|Firm |Ratio | %| 
|--|--|--| 
| A|Debt-assets Ratio  |65% | 
| B| Debt-assets Ratio|45% | 
| A| ROA|5% | 
| B| ROA| 9%|

*Firm A:*
$$ \begin{aligned}

\text{Debt}& =\text{Debt-Total Assets} \cdot \text{Assets}  \\
& = 65\%\cdot 100\\
& =65
\end{aligned}$$

Debt for Firm A is **65**

*Firm B:*
$$ \begin{aligned}

\text{Debt}& = 45\%\cdot 100\\
& =45
\end{aligned}$$

Debt for Firm B is **45**

Now we can calculate the ROE (Return on Equity) of each firm, but we need to make another assumption. 

In this case, we will *assume* that both firms have equal **equity of 100**.

$$ ROE = ROA \cdot (1+\text{Debt-equity ratio})$$

Know that  *1+ Debt-equity ratio* is considered the Equity Multiplier

We know that the Debt-equity ratio is calculated with the following formula:

$$ \text{Debt-equity ratio} =\frac{\text{Total Debt}}{\text{Total Equity}}

*Firm A:*
$$ \begin{aligned}

ROE& =5\% \cdot\bigg(1+\frac{65}{100}\bigg)\\
& = \boxed{8.25\%}\\

\end{aligned}$$

ROE for Firm A is **8.25%**

*Firm B:*
$$ \begin{aligned}

ROE& =9\% \cdot\bigg(1+\frac{45}{100}\bigg)\\
& = \boxed{13.05\%}\\

\end{aligned}$$

ROE for Firm B is **13.05%**

Assuming the conditions set forth, we can say that **Firm B has a better ROE**. Even though the Equity Multiplier is higher in Firm A the ROA in Firm B is significantly higher, suggesting it is more profitable.
